element.name: Art Deco Dublin: The Kodak Building by Bootle, Traditional Cache (2/1)
element.long-description:
This cache is one in a series highlighting some of Dublin's finest examples of Art Deco architecture. The design movement, which was popular roughly between the two world wars, never had an enormous impact in Ireland. Nevertheless many beautiful buildings were constructed along Art Deco lines, and while many have been demolished, there are still several fine examples to be seen in modern Dublin. This series of caches will bring you to several examples, but is not intended to be a comprehensive list.
The structure of Art Deco is based on mathematical geometric shapes. It was widely considered to be an eclectic form of elegant and stylish modernism, being influenced by a variety of sources. Among them were the so-called "primitive" arts of Africa, Ancient Egypt, and Aztec Mexico, as well as machine-age or streamline technology such as modern aviation, electric lighting, the radio, the ocean liner and the skyscraper.
Art Deco design influences were expressed in fractionated, crystalline, faceted forms of decorative Cubism and Futurism. Other popular themes in Art Deco were trapezoidal, zigzagged, geometric, and jumbled shapes, which can be seen in many early pieces. These were the buildings of the future: sleek, geometric, dramatic. With their cubic forms and zigzag designs, art deco buildings embraced the machine age.
Built in 1932, Kodak Ireland used this building as their warehouse to supply the photographic needs of the Irish market for many years. The building was then painted a dark cream in colour, not their trademark yellow colour. The building has an American look to it which makes it quite distinctive amongst all its redbrick and Georgian neighbours!
Rathmines also houses another distinctive Art Deco building in its impressive Post Office, further up the road at N53 19.281 W6 15.946.
This cache is a nano. Stealth is required in this urban location, and please be aware of the many people who pass by this busy spot.
Sources -
Art Deco Ireland
Archiseek
Retropolis
Architecture.com
element.additional-waypoints:
PO1G41E - Rathmines Post Office
N 53째 19.281 W 006째 15.946
element.url-name: Art Deco Dublin: The Kodak Building

ul.li:
2010-06-04T19:00:00Z : Found it by eve1987
Quick find!
TFTC, eve

2010-06-04T19:00:00Z : Found it by GudrunXY
A quick find with eve1987 on our caching tour through Ireland. TFTC GudrunXY

2010-05-31T19:00:00Z : Found it by Dragonfly57
Great building. Got fed up waiting for the guy on his mobile to go so just went for it. TFTC

2010-05-31T19:00:00Z : Found it by The Who
Had to wait to pounce on this one as a couple of muggles were using those damn infernal mobile phones whilst wandering up and down the street. At least it gave us time to look at the very interesting Art Deco Kodak Building. TFTC.

2010-05-25T19:00:00Z : Found it by tmob
#2416
We looked for this cache during our holidays in Ireland. Six fantastic days, 1800kms driven, and a bunch of caches found. Definitely a great way to get to know this beautiful island!
Founded at night, on our way back to the hotel, the last one.
Thanks for this one... Greetings from Portugal

2010-04-03T19:00:00Z : Write note by Kersti.com
The sixth cache today with EdwardsClan - but I've found it before so just a note that it's here :)

2008-10-11T19:00:00Z : Found it by Kersti.com
This was probably the fastest nano find ever for me. Just took a step back and there she was. Log is damp and shows a couple of rust spots.

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Art Deco Dublin: The Kodak Building
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
This cache is one in a series highlighting some of Dublin's finest examples of Art Deco architecture. The design movement, which was popular roughly between the two world wars, never had an enormous impact in Ireland. Nevertheless many beautiful buildings were constructed along Art Deco lines, and while many have been demolished, there are still several fine examples to be seen in modern Dublin. This series of caches will bring you to several examples, but is not intended to be a comprehensive list.

The structure of Art Deco is based on mathematical geometric shapes. It was widely considered to be an eclectic form of elegant and stylish modernism, being influenced by a variety of sources. Among them were the so-called "primitive" arts of Africa, Ancient Egypt, and Aztec Mexico, as well as machine-age or streamline technology such as modern aviation, electric lighting, the radio, the ocean liner and the skyscraper.

Art Deco design influences were expressed in fractionated, crystalline, faceted forms of decorative Cubism and Futurism. Other popular themes in Art Deco were trapezoidal, zigzagged, geometric, and jumbled shapes, which can be seen in many early pieces. These were the buildings of the future: sleek, geometric, dramatic. With their cubic forms and zigzag designs, art deco buildings embraced the machine age.

Built in 1932, Kodak Ireland used this building as their warehouse to supply the photographic needs of the Irish market for many years. The building was then painted a dark cream in colour, not their trademark yellow colour. The building has an American look to it which makes it quite distinctive amongst all its redbrick and Georgian neighbours!

Rathmines also houses another distinctive Art Deco building in its impressive Post Office, further up the road at N53 19.281 W6 15.946.

This cache is a nano. Stealth is required in this urban location, and please be aware of the many people who pass by this busy spot.
